Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Pun \Pun\, v. t. [See {Pound} to beat.] To pound. [Obs.] [1913 Webster]
He would pun thee into shivers with his fist. --Shak. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Pun \Pun\, n. [Cf. {Pun} to pound, {Pound} to beat.] A play on words which have the same sound but different meanings; an expression in which two different applications of a word present an odd or ludicrous idea; a kind of quibble or equivocation. --Addison. [1913 Webster]
A better put on this word was made on the Beggar's Opera, which, it was said, made Gay rich, and Rich gay. --Walpole. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Pun \Pun\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Punned}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Punning}.] To make puns, or a pun; to use a word in a double sense, especially when the contrast of ideas is ludicrous; to play upon words; to quibble. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Pun \Pun\, v. t. To persuade or affect by a pun. --Addison. [1913 Webster]

pun n : a humorous play on words; "I do it for the pun of it"; "his constant punning irritated her" [syn: {punning}, {wordplay}, {paronomasia}] v : make a play on words; "Japanese like to pun--their language is well suited to punning" [also: {punning}, {punned}]
